word.description: {北京} is *Peking* (which kind of sounds like the Cantonese pronunciation *bāk gīng*, but *Beijing* as it is now spelled is better matched to its Mandarin pronunciation). {烤} is *roast*, and {鴨} is *duck*, so {北京烤鴨} is *Peking roast duck* (or *Beijing roast duck*).

description:
[Peking duck](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peking_duck) is roasted duck known for its crispy skin, sliced and wrapped (by you, the diner) in thin pancakes along with garnishes like spring onion and hoisin or plum sauce. Sometimes thick [bao](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baozi) wrappers are used instead of the pancakes.

**History**

This dish is a favorite of Chinese royalty dating back to the Ming Dynasty and in more modern times served to visiting dignitaries such as Henry Kissinger (in between [war crimes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Trial_of_Henry_Kissinger)).

word.description:
{素} is *vegetarian*, and {鴨} is *duck*, so 素鴨 is *vegetarian duck*.

This dish is often listed as *vegetarian goose*, which is 素鵝 ({鵝} is *goose*).

description: Long before tofu burgers and synthetic meat tech startups, Chinese Buddhists were fashioning mock duck meat from layered sheets of [tofu skin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tofu_skin).
